page_analysis.text_content:
Projections

Architectural relief
features such as bay
windows are pleasant
additions to a house
design and are
encouraged. If they
meet certain design
criteria they do not
count toward gross
floor area.

Bay windows

Bay windows that meet the design criteria below are considered to be decorative
architectural features and do NOT count toward gross floor area.

Design criteria for bay windows that do not count:

    • Bottom of feature must be at least 18" above the floor joists
    • Exterior supports must be features like corbels and/or brackets
      rather than solid walls
    • At least 50% of the surface is glass

Note: Bay windows that ex-
tend higher than the struc-
ture's roof are considered
to be dormers and count to-
ward gross floor area.

Fig 13 Bay windows

2' max. from bay window
surface to facade surface
(Typical all)

18" min. from top of
floor to bottom of
baywindow structure

A
Does NOT count

B
Counts because floor
joists continue into the
bay window

C & D
Count because of exterior skirt wall
(angled or straight)

E
Counts because the
surface is not at least
50% glass

Code sections
18.04.030(a)(65)
18.12.040(b)Table 3

18

visual_elements.description:
Figure titled 'Fig 13 Bay windows' illustrates five different cross-section diagrams of bay windows, labeled A, B, C, D, and E, to show which configurations count toward gross floor area and which do not. Diagram A is annotated with dimensional requirements. 
- Diagram A: Shows a bay window supported by brackets. It is labeled 'Does NOT count'. It has two annotations: '2' max. from bay window surface to facade surface (Typical all)' pointing to the horizontal projection, and '18" min. from top of floor to bottom of baywindow structure' pointing to the vertical clearance above the floor joists.
- Diagram B: Shows a bay window where the floor joists extend into the bay window structure. It is labeled 'Counts because floor joists continue into the bay window'.
- Diagram C & D: Shows two variations of a bay window supported by a solid exterior skirt wall, one angled and one straight. It is labeled 'Count because of exterior skirt wall (angled or straight)'.
- Diagram E: Shows a bay window that is mostly a solid wall with a small window opening. It is labeled 'Counts because the surface is not at least 50% glass'.
visual_elements.location: Middle and bottom of the main content area

visual_elements.description: A dark grey vertical bar on the left side of the page contains the main topic heading 'Projections', introductory text, and 'Code sections'.
A dark grey box contains a 'Note' regarding bay windows that extend higher than the structure's roof.
visual_elements.location: Middle right of the main content area

technical_specifications.parameter: Bay window height above floor joists

subheadings: Design criteria for bay windows that do not count:
sections: Main content area with title, criteria, figure, and note

additional_notes: The page number '18' is located at the bottom left corner of the page.
The phrase 'do NOT' is capitalized for emphasis in the main content area.
The text 'feature' in the first bullet point appears to be misspelled as 'teature' in the original document.
The text 'features' in the second bullet point appears to be misspelled as 'teatures' in the original document.
